Qualities of Kūṭadanta [dn5:5.0]: Well born on both mother's and father's side
Recites and remembers the hymns, and has mastered the three Vedas
Attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty
A good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning
Teaches the teachers of many, and teaches three hundred students to recite the hymns
Old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life
Honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and the brahmin Pokkharasāti
Lives in Khāṇumata, a crown property given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.
The Qualities of the Buddha [dn5:7.0]: He is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, irrefutable and impeccable in questions of ancestry back to the seventh paternal generation.
When he went forth he abandoned a large family circle.
When he went forth he abandoned abundant gold coin and bullion stored in dungeons and towers.
He went forth from the lay life to homelessness while still a youth, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
Though his mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces, he shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He is magnificent, splendid, remarkable to behold.
He is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is noble and skillful.
He’s a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
He’s a teacher of teachers.
He has ended sensual desire, and is rid of caprice.
He teaches the efficacy of deeds and action. He doesn’t wish any harm upon the community of brahmins.
He went forth from an eminent family of unbroken aristocratic lineage.
He went forth from a rich, affluent, and wealthy family.
People come from distant lands and distant countries to question him.
Many thousands of deities have gone for refuge for life to him.

He has this good reputation: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
He has the thirty-two marks of a great man.
He is welcoming, congenial, polite, smiling, open, the first to speak.
He’s honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by the four assemblies.
Many gods and humans are devoted to him.
While he is residing in a village or town, non-human entities do not harass them.

He leads an order and a community, and teaches a community, and is said to be the best of the various religious founders. He didn’t come by his fame in the same ways as those other ascetics and brahmins. Rather, he came by his fame due to his supreme knowledge and conduct.
King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama.
King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama.
The brahmin Pokkharasāti and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama.
He’s honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Bimbisāra of Magadha, King Pasenadi of Kosala, and the brahmin Pokkharasāti.
The plan to uproot the outlaw threat (a: Let the king provide seed and fodder for those in the realm who work in farming and raising cattle.
Let the king provide funding for those who work in trade.
Let the king guarantee food and wages for those in government service.
The actions taken by the king (a causal: The king agreed with the high priest’s advice and followed his recommendation.
The king eradicated the outlaw threat.
The country was secured as a sanctuary, free of being harried and oppressed.
The happy people, with joy in their hearts, dancing with children at their breast, dwell as if their houses were wide open.
The four consenting factions [dn5:12.0]: Well-off householders, both of town and country
The four accessories to the sacrifice [d: Well-off householders, both of town and country
The eight factors possessed by King Mahā: Well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, irrefutable and impeccable in questions of ancestry back to the seventh paternal generation
Attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty
Rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, lots of money and grain, and a full treasury and storehouses
Powerful, having an army of four divisions that was obedient and carried out instructions
Faithful, generous, a donor, his door always open. He was a well-spring of support, making merit with ascetics and brahmins, for paupers, vagrants, travelers, and beggars
Very learned in diverse fields of learning. He understood the meaning of diverse statements, saying: ‘This is what that statement means; that is what this statement means.’
Astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present

The ten respects in which the high pries: Those who kill living creatures and those who refrain from killing living creatures
Those who steal and those who refrain from stealing
Those who commit sexual misconduct and those who refrain from committing sexual misconduct
Those who lie and those who refrain from lying
Those who use divisive speech and those who refrain from using divisive speech
Those who use harsh speech and those who refrain from using harsh speech
Those who talk nonsense and those who refrain from talking nonsense
Those who are covetous and those who are not covetous
Those who have ill will and those who do not have ill will
Those who have wrong view and those who have right view
The sixteen respects in which the high p: The king did indeed announce the sacrifice to the aristocrat vassals of town and country
The king did indeed announce the sacrifice to the ministers and counselors, well-to-do brahmins, and well-off householders, both of town and country
The king does indeed possess the eight factors
The high priest does indeed possess the four factors
The things that were not done in the sac: No chickens or pigs were killed
No trees were felled for the sacrificial post
No grass was reaped to strew over the place of sacrifice
No bondservants, employees, or workers did their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces
The factions that set up gifts [dn5:17.0: The aristocrat vassals of town and country set up gifts to the east of the sacrificial pit
The ministers and counselors of town and country set up gifts to the south of the sacrificial pit
The well-to-do brahmins of town and country set up gifts to the west of the sacrificial pit
The well-off householders of town and country set up gifts to the north of the sacrificial pit
Sacrifices that have fewer requirements: Regular gifts as ongoing family sacrifice given specially to ethical renunciates
Giving a dwelling specially for the Saṅgha of the four quarters
Going for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha
Undertaking the training rules to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and alcoholic drinks that cause negligence
A Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha
A mendicant is accomplished in ethics
They enter and remain in the first absorption
They enter and remain in the second absorption
They enter and remain in the third absorption
They enter and remain in the fourth absorption
They extend and project the mind toward knowledge and vision
They understand that there is no return to any state of existence.
